dc:description:
GP1BB was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Bernard-Soulier syndrome in 1997 (Kunishima et al., PMID: 9116284). At least 33 unique variants (e.g. missense, nonsense, and frameshifts) have been reported in humans. The unifying feature of all of the mutations is the
ability of the mutation to disrupt the assembly and/or function of a surface-expressed GP Ib-IX-V complex. How individual mutations affect complex assembly or surface expression can be variable. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and
experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 8 probands in 8 publications (PMIDs: 9116284, 12693941, 12958615, 10887115, 12447957, 12945881, 16409472, 16978236). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 3 additional family members. More
evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic and experimental evidence has been reached. This gene-disease association is supported by its biochemical function in the GP1b platelet receptor for VWF (PMID: 3258770), its protein interactions with GP1BA
and GP9 (PMID: 808914), functional alteration in non-patient cells (PMID: 16409472), a knock-out animal model (PMID: 15213102), and rescue of the animal model with human GP1BB (PMID: 27148783). In summary, GP1BB is definitively associated with autosomal recessive
Bernard-Soulier syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. Of note, this gene has also been implicated in autosomal dominant isolated inherited macrothrombocytopenia
(MONDO:0016361). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found interfamilial phenotypic variability is observed between individuals harboring the same genetic variant between different inheritance patterns and the difference in the inheritance
pattern for the disease entities is representative of a continuum of disease, i.e. mild carrier phenotypic features are observed in recessive disease. Thus the disease entities were lumped and the well-established autosomal recessive inheritance pattern has been curated here;
additional mono-allelic manifestations have also been reported (PMIDs: 28064200, 30609015, 25370924, 29527674).

evidence.dc:description: The null mouse model, in which a targeting vector replaced GP Ibβ exon 2 with a neo-r cassette, recapitulates human phenotypes of large platelets, thrombocytopenia, and prolonged bleeding times. Similar unaffected, intermediate, and affected phenotypes were observed in WT, heterozygous, and homozygous mice as is seen in normal, carrier, and affected humans; heterozygotes had an intermediate platelet count but bleeding time was not prolonged.

The expression of a mouse GP Ib-IX complex on the surface of platelets from mice with altered GP Ibβ alleles was analyzed by flow cytometry. As shown in Figure 2A, GP IbβNull platelets have no detectable GP Ib-IX complex. A hallmark feature of Bernard-Soulier platelets is their large size, and this was apparent for GP IbβNull platelets by monitoring their forward-light scatter profile (Figure 2C). A decrease in circulating platelet counts was significant for both GP IbβHet and GP IbβNull animals (Table 1). Tail bleeding times were determined for each of the 3 genotypes (Figure 3), and GP IbβNull animals display a severe bleeding phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kato2004 Mouse

evidence.dc:description: Macrothrombocytopenia was substantially, but not fully, corrected, with platelet sizes increased by 20% and platelet counts decreased by 40% as compared with wild‐type mice. Use of a human subunit for rescue, less than 100% transduction efficiency and inappropriate control mice (WT instead of transplanted mice) could explain this partial correction. However, GPIb‐IX rescue did result in recovery of VWF binding and full correction of the bleeding diathesis.

hGPIbβ containing hematopoietic progenitors transplanted into the bone marrow of GPIbβnull mice rescued GPIb‐IX expression in 97% of circulating platelets as measured by flow cytometry (Fig. 1A-B). These platelets efficiently adhered to a surface coated with VWF and extended filopodia on a VWF matrix (Fig. 2A-C), demonstrating the restoration of GPIb‐dependent adhesive and signaling properties. These mice also exhibited less severe macrothrombocytopenia (Fig. 1C-E) and had normal tail bleeding times (Fig. 2D) as compared with GPIbβnull mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Strassel2016_Rescue

evidence.dc:description: Reaon(s) for score change	The cDNA encoding each subunit of the GPIb–IX complex was subcloned individually into the pDX expression vector. The mutated sequence was introduced into the expression vector by replacing a fragment of GPIbb cDNA by the equivalent fragment obtained by PCR amplification from the patient’s genomic DNA. Chinese Hamster Ovary cells stably expressing the GPIba and GPIX subunits were transfected with either WT or variant pDX-GP1BB plasmids.

Flow cytometry revealed a low level of surface GPIb-beta (Fig. 4), GPIX was similarly low and GP1b-alpha was at ~30% WT levels. The subcellular distribution was analyzed by confocal fluorescence and found to have a mainly intracellular thin vesicular appearance, as opposed to surface expression. The GPIb-beta found on the surface indicated a lack of association with GPIb-alpha by coIP (Figure 5). And alteration of adhesive function was observed when mutant cells adhered to a VWF coated surface at only 58% WT levels, due to a dramatic decrease in number and length of filopodia and a shape change defect (Figure 6).
evidence.rdfs:label: Strassel2006

evidence.dc:description: Antibodies to GPIb inhibit aggregation of platelets normally mediated by ADP and vWF released from platelets at high shear stress.
GP1b functions as a platelet receptor for VWF and facilitates platelet adherence to the vascular subendothelium and agglutination. Defects in the complex result in a bleeding tendency.
evidence.rdfs:label: Platelet Aggregation

evidence.dc:description: Protein interaction was shown between GP1BB and GP1BA as well as between GP1BB and GP9. All three of which are genes associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Developed cell lines that stably express every combination of two GP1B subunits: GP1BA with GP1BB (CHO AB cells), GP1BA with GP9(CHO A9 cells), and GP1BB with GP9 (CHO B9 cells). Looked at interaction via fluorescence and immunoprecipitation.The two transfected subunits colocalized in CHO AB cells and in CHO B9 cells but were often found in completely distinct compartments in CHO A9 cells. Coimmunoprecipitation occurred similarly, between GP1A/GP1B and GP1B/GP9 but not GP1A/GP9.
evidence.rdfs:label: Lopez1994

evidence.dc:description: This 13 bp deletion would cause a frameshift, resulting in synthesis of a truncated GPIbβ polypeptide composed of 34 amino acids, the first 12 amino acids being the N-terminal sequence of the signal peptide of GPIbβ, and the following 22 amino acids creating an indifferent polypeptide sequence. The mutation causes null synthesis of the mature GPIbβ protein.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic  DNA  isolated  from  peripheral  blood  mononuclear cells was PCR-amplified   over the entire   coding   region and sequenced  by  a direct  sequencing   method.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: platelet  count  was  35x10^9/l, bleeding  time  was  longer  than  10 min.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: GP1BB and GP9 were sequenced for potential pathogenic variants.

evidence.dc:description: 448delG causes a frameshift and the addition of 42 altered amino acids before premature termination. The wild-type or mutant GP1BB cDNA construct was transiently cotransfected with wild-type GPIba and GPIX into 293T cells and analysed by flow cytometry. With WT GPIbb each polypeptide was detected on the transfected cell surface. When the cells were transfected with GPIbbSer147 cDNA, each subunit was also expressed on the cell surface, whereas none of the subunit was detected with GPIbb448delG. Similarly, no expression of either chain was observed in CHOa9cells stably transfected with GPIbb448delG cDNA. Under non-reducing conditions, an anti-GPIbb polyclonal antibody recognized a high molecular weight band corresponding to non-reduced GPIb in the 293T cells transfected with the wild-type GPIbb, wild-type GPIba, and GPIX cDNAs. In the same conditions, however, the antibody detected only a small molecular weight band, corresponding to the individual GPIbb subunit, with Ser147, indicating there was no disulfide-linked association between GPIba and mutant GPIbbs.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kunishima2006_Patient
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral blood leukocytes and the entire coding region of GB1BB was amplified then subjected to direct cycle sequence analysis.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Theplatelet count, determined by manual counting, wasconsistently low (10–60x10^9/L). Duke’s bleedingtime was slightly prolonged (6.5–8 min; normalrange, 2–5 min)
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Entire coding region of GP1BA and GP9 were sequenced for potential pathogenic variants.

evidence.dc:description: The nonsense Trp46Ter is predicted to cause premature termination of translation prior to the region necessary for disulfide bridge formation with GPIb-alpha. Transient co-expression of Trp46Ter in HEK 293T cells with wild-type GPIbα and GPIX did not result in enhanced surface expression of the GPIbα-GPIX complex (as with normal GPIbβ). Similar results were obtained when plasmids encoding normal and mutant GPIbβ were transiently transfected into CHOαIX cells.

evidence.rdfs:label: Moran_Patient
evidence.detectionMethod: Direct sequence analysis of the entire coding region of PCR-amplified GPIbβ from the patient was performed.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Sequencing of GPIbα and GPIX identified no abnormalities. Using G-banded metaphase chromosomes, no deletion on either of the chromosome 22 homologues was detected. Coagulation studies showed no deficiency of factor V, VII, or VIII.

evidence.dc:description: Too few segregations.
evidence.rdfs:label: Watanabe2003 Family

evidence.dc:description: Too few segregations.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kunishima1997 Family

member.rdfs:label: Patient A.K.
member.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral blood lymphocytes, amplified by PCR, cloned and sequenced over the entire coding region.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Duke's bleeding time was moderately prolonged (9.5 minutes; normal range, 2 to 5 minutes). Her platelet mean diameter was 7.7 μm.
member.previousTestingDescription: No mutations identified in vWF A2 domain or the GP1BA coding sequence.

evidence.dc:description: To few affected individuals.
evidence.rdfs:label: Gonzalez-Manchon2003 Family

member.rdfs:label: Patient 1
member.detectionMethod: A  PCR product was obtained from genomic DNA  using a pair of GPIbβ oligonucleotides and direct DNA sequencing of the amplification products was performed.
member.phenotypeFreeText: platelet counts have ranged from 30,000 to 40,000/μl, and a bleeding time longer than 15 min
member.previousTestingDescription: The entire coding sequences of GP1BA and GP9 were analyzed for potential pathogenic variants.

evidence.dc:description: The missense variant Asn89Thr is within a highly conserved residue of the COOH region flanking the LRR motif. The variant was cotransfected in CHO cells with wild-type GPIbα and GPIX and FACS analysis showed that none of the GPIbα-GPIX complex proteins reached the surface (contrary to the normal GPIbβ). Confocal microscopy and western blotting confirmed the mutated protein was present but retained in internal compartments.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient S.B.
evidence.detectionMethod: DNA was extracted from citrated blood, amplified for GPIbβ and sequencing was carried out on PCR products.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: His platelet count is low at ≈40 × 10^3 per μL
evidence.previousTestingDescription: GP1BA and GP9 were sequenced for potential causative variants.

evidence.dc:description: Variant 16038 (Tyr113Cys) creates a new Cysteine residue within a probable disulfide loop, potentially allowing for a disulfide bond within GPIb-beta and preventing the normal disulfide bond with GPIb-alpha. This is supported by immunoblot analysis (Figure 5) in which nonreduced patient platelets had decreased intensity for the 170-kD band corresponding to the disulfide bonded GPIb-beta/GPIb-alpha entity.

This frameshift mutation results in 154 novel amino acids before reaching a predicted stop codon, increasing the size of the protein by 12 kDa. Chinese Hamster Ovary cells stably expressing the GPIba and GPIX subunits were transfected with pDX expression vectors containing WT or variant GP1BB; the mutant protein was produced but was inefficiently transported to the plasma membrane and did not associate with GP1b-alpha.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient RK
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was extracted from citrated blood, amplified for GP1BB, and sequenced.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: platelet counts typically in the range of 3–15x10^9/L
evidence.previousTestingDescription: GP1BA and GP9 were sequenced for potential pathogenic variants.

evidence.dc:description: The predicted effect of this Cys30Tyr substitution would be the disruption of the Cys5-Cys7 intramolecular disulfide bond and the alteration of the loop-within-a-loop structure of GPIbβ. Cotransfection of CHO cells with expression vectors coding for normal GPIbα and GPIX, and either normal or mutant GPIbβ, revealed no significant binding of the anti-GPIbα antibody, detected by flow cytometry, in cells transfected with the mutant version.

The nonsense variant Trp148Ter is predicted to cause premature termination of translation. Transient coexpression of Trp148Ter in HEK 293T cells with wild-type GPIbα and GPIX did not result in enhanced surface expression of the GPIbα-GPIX complex (as with normal GPIbβ). No GPIbβ was detectable in the cells transfected with the variant.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient TF
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral blood leukocytes, the entire coding region of GP1BB was PCR amplified, fragments subjected to direct cycle sequence analysis.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: platelet count was moderately decreased (80–100) × 10^9/L, Duke’s bleeding time was longer than 10 min (normal range, 2–5 min)
evidence.previousTestingDescription: The entire coding regions of GP1BA and GP9 were sequenced with no abnormalities.
